preface.p: This XML file contains examples of the elements that are available in the Helpmanual DTD. If you are not sure about an element in the Helpmanual DTD, you can consult this file to see examples of how to use the element.

body.p: When you first open this document in OxygenXML, you will see the XML elements. You can see a WYSIWYG view of the XML file by clicking the Author tab in the lower left corner of the main content pane. This view will give you an approximate idea of what the document will look like after conversion to HTML. The WYSIWYG view uses a CSS style sheet to render the elements in <oXygen> XML Editor.

While you are working on your document, you will probably find it easier to work in Tags On view, where you can clearly see the XML elements. To switch to Tags On view, select Author > Tags with Attributes.. You will then be able to easily add new elements. You can also switch to the different views available from the Author menu.
Below you can see how this file displays in <oXygen> XML Editor in Author view in No Tags view and Tags with attributes view.
The front element Is the first element in the Helpmanual DTD. It contains the text that will display on the first page.
The front element contains a required title element. Insert the title for your manual or report inside the title element. The front element also contains some optional elements:

ul.li: author: The author of the document.
version: The version of the document.
date: The date the document was completed.
preface: The preface element contains one or more p elements. Each p element contains a separate paragraph. You can use this element to add a brief introduction to your report or manual.

body.p: The primary element in the Helpmanual DTD is the topic element. When you write your report or manual, you will use a separate topic element for each concept, task, or topic.

After you create your XML file, you will publish the file to HTML. The topic element generates a separate page when outputting to HTML, so after you publish your XML file you will have a set of linked HTML pages.
If you want your content to display on a separate web page, you should insert a new topic element.
The topic element contains the following elements:

ul.li: title : The title element is required. Enter your page title in the title element. When you insert a topic element, you will see a number inside the title element. This numbering will help you to keep track of the order of the topics and the ways that they are nested. Note that the numbering will display in the output by default.
body - The body element is required. The body element contains the main elements for the page - paragraphs, lists, tables, etc.
related-links - The related-links element is optional. You can use this element to add a set of links to other topics.
topic - If you have a group of related topics, add a nested topic so that they appear in the TOC as indented topics. Nested topics show the hierarchical relationship in the table of contents.

body.p: After you publish the XML file to HTML, you will see a Next and Previous navigation link in the upper right corner and lower right corner that links the topics.

This topic is nested inside its parent topic. In Author view, the title for each topic level shows in a different font. The titles at the primary level show in a blue font. The titles in nested topics show as a black font. Each level in the hierarchy shows the topic title in a smaller font.

section.p: You can verify the nesting of the topics using the Outline pane. The Outline pane shows you where you are in the hierarchy. In the graphic below, we can see that there is a topic nested in the highlighted topic. Note that each topic shows as indented when it is nested.

You can also see where you are in the hierarchy by looking in the upper left corner of the main Content pane. You will see there the path from the document root to the current element. For example, if we look at the path now, we can see that this element has the following path:

section.title: Title numbering
section.p: By default, when you transform to HTML, numbering will display in the titles. If you do not want the title numbers to display in the HTML output, you will need to add an attribute to the helpmanual element. If you add the topicnumbers attribute to the helpmanual element with a value of "no", the title numbering will not display in the HTML output.

section.title: Linking to nested topics
section.p: You can automatically add links to nested topics. These links will display only after you transform the XML file to HTML. If you want to display the links to nested topics in the output, add the class attribute to the parent topic element with a value of nestedtopiclinks. In the screenshot below, the links to the nested topics at the bottom of the topic display after applying the transformation in <oXygen> XML Editor.

body.p: If you want to insert notes, tips or cautions, you can use the note tag. The note tag has a type attribute with 3 possible values that specify the type of note: note, tip or caution.

When you add the type attribute, you will see that some text is added to the beginning of the note. The text "Note:", "Tip:", or "Caution:" will be added to the beginning. This will also appear in the HTML output files.

Drop-down links allow you to compress related chunks of information in the same topic. By using a drop-down link, you can present a much cleaner look by displaying information only when the reader requests it.

If you create an FAQ topic or a Troubleshooting topic, you might it useful to use a drop-down link. If your topic contains a large number of FAQs or troubleshooting tips, you will find that the use of drop-down links will make it much easier for the user to locate information. In the example below, we present a few FAQs.

dropdownlink.linktext: How do I insert a drop-down link?

dropdowntext.p: To insert a drop-down link, insert the dropdownlink tag. The dropdownlink tag contains two required elements: linktext and dropdowntext:

ul.li: linktext: Insert a short phrase or sentence that describes the information that will appear if the user clicks on the link. The content of the linktext element will show as a weblink after applying the stylesheets.

dropdowntext: The content of this element will not initially display when you view it in the browser after publishing your XML file to HTML. The user will need to first click the link created by the linktext element before seeing the content of the dropdowntext element.

dropdownlink.linktext: Are there other uses for drop-down links besides FAQs?

dropdowntext.p: Yes. You can use dropdown links wherever you want to show some content only if the user clicks the link. For example, let's say you are writing an online manual, and there are two different methods to complete a specific task. You could insert two drop-down links for each method.

The image element must be inserted inside a block element such as a paragraph, while the fig element is inserted as a block level element, outside of a paragraph. If you want your graphic to display on a separate line, use the fig element.

body.note: If you are working in a group and the other group members are using XMLSpy, note that when you view XML files that were created in XMLSpy, you will not see the images in OxygenXML in Author mode. section.title: Available attributes for tables
section.p: The table below lists the available attributes for a table.
Note that the table below is aligned to the center of the page by setting the align property for the table element.

ul.li: width - table width. Example: <table width="500px">
align: Aligns the table to the left (default), center, or right.
border - Specifies if the table shows a border. Example: <table border="1">
rules - Specifies which rules (the lines in the table) should display. Example: <table rules="rows">
cellpadding - Specifies the amount of space between the table cell wall and the table cell content. Example: <table cellpadding="2px">
cellspacing - Specifies the amount of space around the table cell walls. Example: <table cellspacing="5px">
bgcolor - Specifies the background color of a table row or table cell. Example: <table bgcolor="lightgrey">

tr.td: table row, table column, table cell

ul.li: bgcolor - Specifies the background color of a table row or table cell. Example: <table bgcolor="lightgrey">.

width - Specifies the width of the table cell, column or row. If you specify the width for one table cell, all of the table cells in the same column will have the same width. Example: <td width="50px">.
height: Specifies the height of a row or table cell. Example: <tr height="40px">.
align - Specifies the alignment of the content of the table cell. Example: <td align="center">.
valign - Specifies the vertical alignment of the content of the table cell. Example: <td valign="middle">.

section.title: Numbered lists
section.p: Use the ol tag to create numbered lists. Note that each individual list item in the list should be enclosed by an li tag.

section.p: Bullet lists use the ul tag. Like the ol tag, they also use the li tag for each individual list item inside the list. You can specify the type of bullet (circle, disc, or square) by specifying a value for the bullet attribute of the ul tag

body.p: If you want to insert subtitles in your topic, you will need to first insert the section element. The section element contains the same elements as the body element such as paragraphs, lists, and tables. But it has an additional element - the title element - that allows you to insert subtitles. If your topic describes several concepts or tasks, use the section element to group each concept or task.

body.p: You can add two types of comments:

ul.li: comment - The comment element is used to insert a hidden comment. These comments display in a red font in the Author view so that they are easier to view. When you convert your XML file to HTML, the comment will be hidden. This is a comment.

mcomment - The mcomment element is used for marker's comments. These comments display in a green font in the Author view. When your assignment is submitted for marking, the marker will use this element to add comments. You do not need to use this element in your assignments.

body.p: You can insert links inside paragraphs, lists, and tables. Several types of links are available, including web links, links between topics, and glossary links.

section.title: Web links
section.p: Use the weblink element to create a link to a Web site. The weblink element has a required attribute: href. Enter the website URL in the href attribute.
section.note: Make sure that you include http:// at the beginning of the URL.

section.title: Links between topics
section.p: Use the xref element to link to another topic. The url of the xref element should be the same as the id attribute of the topic you are linking to.

In the example below, a topic element has an id attribute with a value of "topic2". The p tag below is located in another topic element. The xref tag has an id attribute of "topic2". After the XML file is published to HTML, the content in the xref tag will link to the first topic below.
The links below use the xref tag and they link to a topic that uses the same id attribute:

Authentic view - This first link has an id attribute of "viewingtags". This means that after we transform the XML document, a link will be created that links to the topic that also has an id attribute of "viewingtags".

Topic element - This second link has an id attribute of "topic". This means that after we transform the XML document, a link will be created that links to the topic that also has an id attribute of "topic".

section.title: Glossary links
section.p: You may also use the xref element to link to a glossary definition. To link to a glossary definition, you must first enter the glossary term in the glossary element. Each individual glossary term needs an id attribute so that you can link to it.

In the example below, the glossary contains a definition for the term "topic". The glossentry element has an id attribute with a value of "topicid". The xref tag below points to the glossary definition by using the value of the id attribute of the glossary definition. The content of the xref tag will display as a link to the glossary definition after publishing the XML file to HTML.

body.p: You can use the b, i, and q elements to apply formatting to letters, words, or phrases.

ul.li: b - The b element formats text as bold text..

q - You can use the q element for inline quotes.

body.p: The style sheets create an index using the words or phrases that are marked up inside the content of the XML file. To add an entry to the index, insert an indexterm element inside a paragraph, list, or table.

In this paragraph, we have included two entries in the index: indexterm and Creating an index. Note that each phrase is located inside an indexterm element. If you view the index, you will see an entry for each index term that links back to this page.

body.p: If you want to add a group of links to the bottom of the topic, you can insert the related-links element. The related-links element contains one or more link elements. Each link element has an id attribute. The id attribute of the link element points to the topic that you are linking to.
When you insert the related-links element, a link element will display. To add an additional link element in Author view, you can just hit Enter on the keyboard and choose the link element.
If you want to add a bibliography, insert the biblio element inside the back element.
The biblio element can contain one or more custmbib elements. Enter each bibliographic entry inside a custmbib element.
body.note: When you insert the biblio element, the page title for the bibliography page is automatically inserted.

body.p: If you want to add a glossary, insert the glossary element inside the back element.
The glossary element can contain one or more glossentry elements. Enter each glossary entry inside a glossentry element. The glossentry element has 2 child elements:

ul.li: glossterm: The glossary term.
glossdef: The glossary definition

body.p: The glossentry element has an optional id attribute. Use the id attribute if you want to link to the glossary definition from another topic element.
body.note: When you insert the glossary element, the page title for the glossary page is automatically inserted.

Uniform Resource Locator. Specifies the location of a specific resource. A URL is divided into several parts. 1. The resource type - A web link uses the http:// to indicate a website. 2. The domain name - This is the name of the domain. An example is www.online-learning.com. 3. The file path - if you are linking to a specific page in a website, you can include the name of the file. For example: links.html. An example of a complete URL is http://www.online-learning.com/contact.html.

When you apply an XSLT style sheet to an XML file, you are transforming the XML file to another format. This is called a transformation. Often you will transform the XML file to HTML, but you might also transform to other formats such as PDF or RTF format.
